thread.title: ACCC boss plays down monitoring scheme cost concerns
thread.title_full: ACCC boss plays down monitoring scheme cost concerns | Business Spectator

author: Supratim Adhikari
title: ACCC boss plays down monitoring scheme cost concerns
text:
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission boss Rod Sims has played down the cost concerns raised by the telcos about a proposed broadband monitoring program, saying that the scheme is likely to cost consumers less than 50 cents a year.
Mr Sims told the ABC that the scheme is likely to cost between two to three million dollars to implement, less than 50 cents per customer per year.
“The amount of money is trivial, this isn’t a red tape issue, this isn’t a cost issue that’s not at play here,” Mr Sims told the ABC.
The Communications ­Alliance — which represents telcos including Telstra, Optus and Vodafone — has warned that the scheme could be a “very expensive solution” and the cost burden will have to be borne by consumers.
However, Mr Sims said that concerns about regulatory overreach and cost impact on consumers are overblown.
“You always expect a bit of a pushback from the companies that will have their performance put up in neon lights, but what we are trying to do is make sure that customers have the same level of information as the telecommunications suppliers do,” he said.
With the NBN rolling out, Mr Sims said that there was need for a monitoring mechanism to ensure that customers were actually receiving the service quality promised by retail service providers and to monitor the speed provisioned on the NBN and whether the service providers have provisioned adequate capacity for their network needs.
The regulator has completed a trial of the service with 90 Melbourne-based volunteers who agreed to have their fixed-line broadband connections monitored, via a hardware probe attached to their modems, for the past three months.
Mr Sims added that there were immediate plans to launch the scheme.
“Whether it happens next year, the year after, or the year after that, I am not sure. We are taking forward our discussions and at this stage we have shown that the concept absolutely works.”
The company rolling out the NBN has welcomed the program and the role it can play in fostering greater competition at a retail level.
NBN Co said it supported the “intent” of the program and ­welcomed the initiative if it helped to create greater competition.
“We look forward to further dialogue with the ACCC on how the program will work in practice, and how the data will be presented and made accessible to consumers,” a NBN Co spokesman told The Australian.
